body:
Thanks for submitting this. Actually Spark SQL/catalyst itself already supports more than 22 fields. It's just that case classes in Scala 2.10 doesn't. As long as the user's class (not case classes) implements the Product interface, it should be fine. 

Instead of introducing a new API, do you mind updating the documentation to indicate that? (i.e. any concrete implementations of Product are fine; case class is merely a special example of that)
thanks. will merge once jenkins is happy.
We should also update the Java API to create Ordering directly (instead of Ordered). It still compiles now, but kind of strange to have Ordered in the Java API that gets converted into Ordering.
Thanks @abhishekkr. I am going to merge #399. Do you mind closing this one?
@shivaram can you take a look at this?

It would be great to not having to introduce algebird. Do you mind updating the PR?

cc @jegonzal and @ankurdave
Sorry it took us a while to respond... there are too many open pull requests!

Thanks I've merged this. But in general we have changed numTasks to numPartitions in the code. We should change all documentations to use numPartitions instead. Do you mind submitting a new PR for that?
Merged build finished. All automated tests passed.

The upcoming Scala 2.11 now supports case classes with more than 22 fields https://issues.scala-lang.org/browse/SI-7296
ok, i will update the doc to indicate this
@mateiz : Do you still think we should try and get this in for 1.0 / is it in a good state to merge?

From the side of the life cycle for component, only stop method is incomplete,  and the initialize code , start code written separately is better

I run SparkPi serveral times, and get different results:
1. With slices < 200, the executors all succeeds, and the framework gives correct result.
2. With slices > 400, executors remain STAGING and quit, leaving empty executor logs. In slave log, I can't see anything useful either: http://pastebin.com/SEhyywSW

Again, with 0.9.1 it works well regardless of how much slices I set.
@rxin thanks for the comments, just addressed that and wait for Jenkins

Changing to `SparkExcepation` will not break the API since `SparkExcepation` is a subclass of `Exception`.
@pwendell  :smile: i think this also closes SPARK-1464 ?
@CodingCat do you mind submitting a separate PR for the Scala files? We can update documentation changes anytime we want.
